messageBody:
Harald Mueller wrote:

> [I confess I didn't read or search for any information about the question
> above - I'll do that on the weekend.
> The reason I jumped to the mailing list is that 2 of us want to write a
> doclet *a few hours from now*, and we want to do TDD ... maybe someone here
> is kind enough to shoot a quick answer at me ...]

I'm sure I'm too late, but....

> The problem/question is: How do you go about writing a class that is deeply
> embedded in a framework (in this case, a doclet in javadoc)?
> >From the first line, the code will consist of lines accessing the huge
> RootDoc data structure created by javadoc and passed into the doclet's start
> method (public static boolean start(RootDoc root)). How do I JUnit and,
> especially, TDD this?

I'm not familiar with the framework, but it appears that you're
implementating a class that will be invoked by the Doclet framework.

Now fortunately, RootDoc is an interface, so we ought to be able to mock
it, or provide a simple implementation of it, to pass in to the method
start(), which I /assume/ you're trying to test-drive.

I would start with a few learning tests to discover what a RootDoc looks
like for a real-life set of Javadocs. Then I would use that information
to understand how to simulate the methods of RootDoc. That would give me
enough information to start test-driving start().

I know this isn't particularly satisfying, but it's what I would do if I
were you. At least you have a pair partner to work with!
